query: Who is responsible for assessing a breach when it happens at a data intermediary?

gold.gold_answer_extended: According to PDPA s.26C(3), when a data intermediary believes a breach occurred while processing data for another organisation, it must notify that organisation without undue delay. The organisation must then conduct the notifiable-breach assessment.

prediction.answer_text: When a data breach occurs at a data intermediary (other than one mentioned in section 26E), the data intermediary must notify the other organisation without undue delay. That other organisation then must conduct an assessment of whether the data breach is a notifiable data breach, as specified in PDPA s.26C(3).

query: If a company collects work emails from a public website, must it comply with PDPA?

gold.gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.4(5) excludes business contact information, so collection of such publicly available work details generally does not trigger PDPA obligations.

prediction.answer_text: Yes, a company must comply with the PDPA if it collects work emails from a public website. Under PDPA s.20(4)(a), an organisation must notify the purpose of collecting personal data, including emails, when entering into an employment relationship. Additionally, PDPA s.11(5) requires the organisation to make available the contact information of designated individuals.

query: If an employee mishandles personal data at work, is the employer treated as having done the act too?

gold.gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.53(1) treats an act or conduct engaged in by an employee in the course of employment as done by the employer as well as by the employee, whether or not the employer knew or approved.

prediction.answer_text: Yes, under PDPA s.53(1), if an employee mishandles personal data in the course of their employment, the employer is treated as having done the act too. This is because the employer is held liable for the employee's actions within the scope of their employment.

query: What can the PDPC regulate about mediation operators under the PDPA?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.48G(4), the Commission, with Ministerial approval, may make regulations covering the standards, fees, record-keeping, reporting, and administration of dispute resolution schemes to give effect to mediation provisions.

prediction.answer_text: I'm not sure; this appears outside the provided statute.
prediction.original_text: Under the PDPA, the PDPC can regulate matters relating to the operation of a dispute resolution scheme by mediation operators. Specifically, the PDPC may make regulations regarding the standards or requirements of services, fees, records to be kept, reports to be submitted, and the administration of the scheme. These regulations are subject to the approval of the Minister, as provided in PDPA s.65(1) and PDPA s.48G(4).

query: If my Wi-Fi was hijacked and messages were sent without my knowledge, am I responsible?

gold.gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48A(5) presumes an owner or authorised user did not send, cause to be sent, or authorise an applicable message if the device/service/network was controlled by another without their knowledge, unless proven otherwise.

PDPA s.36(3) and s.48A(5) state that unless proven otherwise, the owners or authorised users are presumed not to have sent or authorised the messages. A telecommunications service provider who merely provides a service that enables a message to be sent is also presumed not to have sent the message, as per PDPA s.36(2). Therefore, you are not liable for messages sent through a hijacked network.

This applies even if there is no proven gain, as the harm alone constitutes the offence. PDPA s.48E(3) clarifies that this provision is not affected by other laws.

query: When does the PDPA's DNC rules apply to messages sent to Singapore numbers?

prediction.answer_text: The PDPA's DNC rules apply to messages sent to Singapore numbers when the sender is present in Singapore at the time the message is sent (PDPA s.38(0)), or when the recipient is present in Singapore when the message is accessed. Additionally, a person must not send such a message unless they have valid confirmation that the number is not in the register (PDPA s.43(1)).

query: Is ‘I didn’t know’ a defence for managers when a PDPA breach occurs?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Under s.52(2)(b)(iii), a person in management who knew or ought reasonably to have known the offence would be or was being committed, and failed to take all reasonable steps to prevent or stop it, is guilty.

prediction.answer_text: Under PDPA s.48(1), an employee may defend themselves in proceedings for an offence under this Part by proving they acted in good faith in the course of their employment or as instructed by their employer. However, this does not automatically mean that 'I didn't know' is a defence, as the employee must still demonstrate that their actions were in good faith. The specific defence under PDPA s.48(1) requires proof of good faith in the context of their employment, not just a lack of knowledge.

query: If an employer proves practicable steps, does that automatically absolve the employee?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Section 53(2) provides a defence for the person proceeded against as employer. The excerpt does not extend that defence to the employee’s own liability.

prediction.answer_text: Under PDPA s.53(2), if an employer proves they took practicable steps to prevent an employee from committing an offence, it can serve as a defence. However, this does not automatically absolve the employee; the employer must still demonstrate that these steps were indeed practicable and effective in preventing the act. The employee's liability may still depend on other factors, including whether the act was committed in the course of employment.

query: If a company’s chatbot sends promotional messages using a third-party API, is the company responsible?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.37(3)–(4), a business that authorises another (such as an API service) to promote its goods is deemed to have authorised those messages unless it took reasonable steps to stop them.

prediction.answer_text: Under PDPA s.37(3), if the company authorises the chatbot to send promotional messages, it is deemed to have authorised the sending of those messages. However, under PDPA s.48A(4), a telecommunications service provider that merely provides the API service is presumed not to have sent the messages, unless proven otherwise. Therefore, the company may be responsible if it authorised the chatbot, but the third-party API provider may not be held responsible unless it is proven that it sent or authorised the messages.

query: When does the deemed consent by notification rule apply?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.15A(1), the deemed consent by notification framework applies to the collection, use, or disclosure of personal data occurring on or after 1 February 2021.

prediction.answer_text: The deemed consent by notification rule applies when an organisation collects, uses, or discloses personal data about an individual on or after 1 February 2021, as stated in PDPA s.15A(1). This rule is also applicable when the collection, use, or disclosure is for a prescribed purpose, as mentioned in PDPA s.15A(3). Additionally, if the individual is deemed to have consented under section 15 or 15A, then subsection (1) of PDPA s.20 does not apply.

query: What defences are available for improper use of personal data?

gold.gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48E(2) provides defences such as: the data was publicly available (and not known to result from a breach), or the use was allowed or required by another law, court order, or under a reasonable belief of legal right.

prediction.answer_text: Under PDPA s.48E(2), a defence for improper use of personal data includes proving that the personal data was publicly available at the time of use, or that the use was permitted by law, authorised by a court order, or based on a reasonable belief in having the legal right. Additionally, PDPA s.48E(3) clarifies that other laws may still impose obligations or limitations on the use of personal data.

query: Can a business send marketing messages without checking the Do Not Call Register?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.43(1), a person must not send a specified message to a Singapore telephone number unless they have valid confirmation at the time of sending that the number is not listed in the relevant Do Not Call Register.

prediction.answer_text: Under the PDPA, a business must check the Do Not Call Register before sending marketing messages to Singapore telephone numbers, unless the recipient has given clear and unambiguous consent to the message, as evidenced in writing or another form accessible for future reference (PDPA s.43(1) and s.43(4)). Therefore, a business generally cannot send marketing messages without checking the register, unless the recipient has given proper consent.

query: Does section 52A change how evidence is admitted in PDPA prosecutions against associations or partnerships?

prediction.answer_text: No, section 52A does not change how evidence is admitted in PDPA prosecutions against associations or partnerships. According to PDPA s.52A(4), it explicitly states that Chapters 5 and 5A of the Penal Code 1871, as well as the Evidence Act 1893 and any other law or practice regarding the admissibility of evidence, remain applicable. Therefore, the admission of evidence in PDPA prosecutions against unincorporated associations or partnerships is not affected by section 52A.

However, this duty may be excluded if a prescribed law enforcement agency instructs the organisation not to notify, or if the Commission directs otherwise, as stated in PDPA s.26D(6). The notification must include all prescribed information to the best of the organisation's knowledge at the time, as outlined in PDPA s.26D(3).

query: If another company receives notice that my data was corrected, what must it do?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.22(4), when an organisation is notified of a correction to your personal data under subsection (2)(b) or (3), it must correct its records unless it is satisfied on reasonable grounds that the correction should not be made. This ensures consistent data accuracy across organisations.

prediction.answer_text: If another company receives notice that your data was corrected, it must correct the personal data in its possession or under its control unless it is satisfied on reasonable grounds that the correction should not be made, as stated in PDPA s.22(4).

query: What must specified persons under PDPA s.59(1) keep secret?

gold.gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.59(1) requires specified persons to preserve secrecy regarding personal data subject to refusal under s.21, identified confidential matters, and identities of informants, except where disclosure is lawfully required or necessary for duty performance.

prediction.answer_text: Under PDPA s.59(1), specified persons must keep secret any personal data an organisation would be required or authorised to refuse to disclose if it were contained in personal data requested under section 21, whether information exists if an organisation in refusing to provide access under section 21 does not indicate whether the information exists, all matters identified as confidential under subsection (3), and all matters relating to the identity of persons providing information to the Commission.

query: When can PDPC proceed to issue a direction or impose a penalty?

gold.gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48K(4) allows the Commission to decide to give a direction under s.48I or impose a penalty under s.48J(1) after considering filed representations, or upon expiry of the representation period (as extended) if none are made or are withdrawn.

query: If a law enforcement agency collects data under another law, does PDPA still apply?

gold.gold_answer_extended: According to PDPA s.4(6)(b), provisions of other written laws override PDPA duties if there is a conflict.

prediction.answer_text: Yes, PDPA still applies. If a law enforcement agency collects data under another law, the organisation must not inform the individual that the data was disclosed to the agency if the disclosure was made under this Act or any other written law without the individual’s consent, as stated in PDPA s.21(4). Additionally, the organisation has a duty to notify the occurrence of a notifiable data breach, including if it was disclosed to a law enforcement agency under another law, as outlined in PDPA s.26D(9).

Similarly, the PDPC may confirm a refusal to transmit applicable data or direct the porting organisation to transmit it in a specified manner and time under PDPA s.48H(2)(c). Additionally, the PDPC may confirm, reduce, or disallow a fee, or direct the organisation or porting organisation to make a refund to the complainant or receiving organisation under PDPA s.48H(2)(d).

query: Who can bring a private action against an individual for PDPA message offences?

gold.gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48O(1)(b) confers a civil right of action on persons who suffer loss or damage directly from a person’s contravention of Division 3 of Part 9 or section 48B(1).

prediction.answer_text: Under PDPA s.48O(1), a person who suffers loss or damage directly as a result of a contravention by an individual of any provision of Division 3 of Part 9 or section 48B(1) has a right of action. However, an action may not be brought until after the Commission's decision has become final, as stated in PDPA s.48O(2). The individual must be directly affected by the contravention to bring a private action.

query: Is it an offence to disclose confidential PDPC information unlawfully?

query: When is consent considered 'deemed' even if I didn’t explicitly agree?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.15(1), if an individual voluntarily provides personal data to an organisation for a specific purpose and it is reasonable to do so, consent is deemed to have been given for that purpose.

prediction.answer_text: Consent is deemed if you voluntarily provide personal data to an organisation for a specific purpose, as outlined in PDPA s.15(1)(a), and it is reasonable that you would do so. Additionally, from 1 February 2021, consent is deemed if the organisation collects, uses, or discloses personal data through notification, as stated in PDPA s.15A(1). This applies even if you did not explicitly agree.

query: What can I ask a company for under the PDPA if I want to see my data?

gold.gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(1), individuals can request an organisation to provide their personal data in its possession or control, and information about how that data has been or may have been used or disclosed in the year preceding the request. The organisation must provide this as soon as reasonably possible, subject to other subsections limiting disclosure.

prediction.answer_text: I'm not sure; this appears outside the provided statute.
prediction.original_text: Under the PDPA, you can request access to your personal data by asking the company for it directly. According to PDPA s.21(2), an organisation is not required to provide you with your personal data if it is specified in the Fifth Schedule. However, if the organisation can provide the data without excluding any information under subsections (2), (3), and (4), it must do so under PDPA s.21(5). Additionally, the company must inform you of the purpose for which they are collecting, using, or disclosing your data under PDPA s.20(5).

query: Does the PDPA apply to individuals acting in a personal capacity?
